p: We created two bairro-level variables for each SP category: (i) positivity, defined as the proportion of successfully visited sites that were registered as positive for larvae/pupae; and (ii) proximity, defined as the areal proportion of the bairro that falls within a 150-meter buffer area around a positive strategic point. We selected the buffer size using two criteria: (i) expected Aedes mosquito flight distance in an urban setting [ 10, 16, 17]; and (ii) buffer size used by the Brazilian Ministry of Health to define the transmission block area around identified vector oviposition sites [ 62]. For the positivity variable, bairros without an SP visit during an inspection cycle were coded as missing with a missingness indicator variable. The proximity variable was calculated in ArcGIS. To properly associate the presence of mosquito larvae/pupae with monthly dengue virus transmission, SP-related covariates were lagged by a 15-day cycle, as shown in Fig 2.
